moves.1. e4 c5 2. Ne2: This is the Sicilian opening. 2. Ne2 (the Keres variation) is much less played than Nf3. In most cases (like here) it makes no practical difference, but Ne2 sometimes has a good effect of confusing the opponent in an OTB game, especially a blitz
moves.2... Nc6 3. Nbc3 g6: 3.....g6 is meant to develop the DSB (dark-squared bishop) to g7 (called fianchetto), a rather typical procedure in this opening
moves.4. d4: White opens up the lines and clears the centre. This leads to the very typical exchange of pawns in the Sicilian
moves.4... cxd4 5. Nxd4: You may note that 5. Nxd4 had been the same if the knight had stood at f3 (see above)!
moves.5... Bg7 6. Be3 Nf6 7. Bc4 e6 8. O-O O-O: 10. Bc5 is a maneuvre that, via the threat on Rf8, positions the bishop at d6, nicely WITHIN black's defense zone where it cannot be chased away by pawns
moves.10... Re8 11. Bd6 Qb6: 11.....Qb6 is a good aggressive move threatening b2 and preventing advance of white's f pawn
moves.12. Na4: 12. Na4 protects the pawn and chases the Q away at the same time
moves.12... Qa5: 12....Qa5 attacks the knight, but this knight's idea was all the time - not to harass the queen - but to reach the position c5, another piece within the black bastion!
moves.13. Nc5 Nxe4: 13.....Nxe4 is a serious blunder. The knight at c5 covers this square!
moves.15. Rb1 Ba3: 15....Ba3 is another serious mistake, leaving the a1-h8 diagonal, because.....
moves.16. Nf6+ Kg7 17. Nxe8+: black resigned, and would be checkmated shortly
